In my view, Season 2 of Avatar: The Last Airbender strikes the ideal balance in tone and storytelling compared to the other seasons. It doesn't have the overly lighthearted feel of Season 1 nor the heavy seriousness of Season 3, but finds a nice middle ground that works well. Although it doesn't introduce as many new major characters as Season 1, it features some of the most memorable scenes and moments in the entire series. While Season 3 delves deeper thematically, Season 2 still offers plenty in terms of character development, plot progression and emotional resonance. This season introduces and highlights on fan favorite characters like Toph and Azula, giving them arcs that elevate the story. Overall, Season 2 exemplifies what makes Avatar great - a fascinating tale told through a blend of comedy, adventure, gravitas and heart.
Is this even better than Season 1? I don't know. I just know both were amazing.
With seasons like this one, it's no wonder why Avatar: The Last Airbender is viewed as the greatest animated series of all time.

This series is one of the best ever on television. The first series started as a kid show, and quickly grew into more. This season takes off, gives you high adventure and a plot that spans the world. Fantastically written, Avatar season 2 just gets better and better

Greatest tv series I have ever watched and rewatched. I watched it as a kid growing up and enjoyed it a lot. Then during my teenage years, I rewatched it with my sister and my parents. Lately, I rewatched it at university with my Uni friends. Each time I appreciated a completely different aspect of the show. It is utter perfection in world-building, character development and the telling of a good story. All can appreciate the show regardless of age or gender or race. It is the epitome of storytelling.

I love the way it portrays the characters and humanizes even those who are in the wrong. I cannot name a single poorly-developed character. I could go on and on about how I admire it's philosophical and spiritual foundation. It encourages the pursuit of learning and living by truth, and it teaches that all life is sacred. I love how it takes the highlights of cultures and histories around the world and brings them together in a unified story of understanding. At the plot's climax, it teaches the importance of justice through non-violence. Throughout the story it shows the blessings of working hard enough to become a master while still maintaining a child-like spirit.
Still my favorite animated show ever

Probably the best season of a cartoon I've ever seen.  It is truly flawless in every way you can imagine and more.  I cannot even conceive the pure genius that went into every second of this, "Simple kids' cartoon."  The story points both masterfully finish old plotlines while simultaneously setting up the most important arcs and plot threads of the series.  Also, Toph is the single best character, animation or live action, of all time.

I already really liked season one, I really freaking liked season two, and if this pattern continues, I'm going to freaking love season three! ONTO THE NEXT BOOK: FIRE!

One of the best television shows, not just kids' shows, of a generation. Avatar teaches grace, humility, forgiveness and other poignant life lessons with an optimistic outlook. From the hilarious references to former professional wrestlers turned Hollywood actors (The Boulder) to the absolutely heartbreaking and moving rendition of Leaves From the Vine by Uncle Iroh, this show truly runs the full gamut of human emotions. An absolute must watch.

You'll like it if: You have a heart.  
You won't like it if: You are determined to hate cartoons.
One of the best-animated shows ever.

There you go…that's what I call the best thing Nickelodeon has ever animated. I like this season so much more then the first season that it's frightening. And remember, I gave the first season a pretty positive review, but it's nowhere near the excellence of this season. The story here I'm not really going to go into so much detail about because once again, the over arcing story is great, just like the last season. But it's when the show is episodic that's really hit or miss. This season, however, was a grand slam in that department. The characters that they met weren't annoying, and if they were, not as annoying as they were in the first season, biggest example of that is with Jet. Speaking of Jet…he's back for this season, and is actually fixed, which is a sigh of relief. Let's be honest, the characters in a tv show is what is going to keep you interested, not the story. Avatar is no exception, and the main characters are great. Aang and Katara are still great, but Sokka might have just became my favorite animated Nickelodeon character this season. He went from a hit or miss funny guy to arguably the best character in the season. But hey, our new member of the group, Toph, is also a great character, especially with her being blind, that seemed like a great touch. Our new villains, Azula and the other two, are also great and insane, and are better "villains" but not better characters. Now, I think Sokka is my favorite character this season…but the best characters were Iroh and Zuko. I'm not gonna lie, but I cared about them a lot more then the main characters, and I still cared about the main group, but I thought what Zuko was going through was better. And I think that's all I have to say. If you liked the first season enough, you'll love this one, cause all the problems that season had are all fixed. Please, if you have the opportunity to watch this show, please do, you won't regret it. I know I haven't, and I can't WAIT to watch for season 3!

Undoubtedly, Avatar is a great show. It is a fun adventure series to watch but it has its flaws. The story is well-written as well as the characters. I would even argue that Zuko is one of the best characters to ever be written. However, the love story is inappropriate for the characters' age and even for the target audience. Speaking of which, having a very young target audience it impacted the progression of the show, making it too fast. Those are some of the flaws I've found in this show but other than that I would say the show is great. The direction is fresh and original.
Flawless. Amazing characters, amazing plot, amazing finale, just PERFECT.

This season of Avatar: The Last Airbender takes everything you loved about the first season and cranks them up to 100, we are introduced to a new villain in the form of a teenaged Fire Nation Princess named Azula. Princess Azula is an absolute perfectionist and a true prodigy when it comes to her blue-fired firebending, and she is determined on capturing the Avatar and her brother Zuko. Team Avatar also gain a new ally in the form of a blind, smart alec, earthbending girl, these two new characters are welcomed editions to the show. We get to watch as Zuko struggles to do the right thing as the line between right and wrong grows increasingly more blurred for the estranged teenager, his story arc is easily my favorite this season Zuko goes through a tremendous amount of development throughout this season and I loved every minute of it. This season overall was completely perfect and everything you could've wanted out of the sequel season to season one, our characters are developing a lot through the season some for the best and others for the worst and I enjoyed watching every minute of it, both the good and the bad.
This season introduced some of the greatest characters in cartoon history. The combination of skill and teamwork is just incredible and amazing to watch!

Absolutely brilliant. The incredible action, story, characters, and writing overshadow any minor nitpick. Upon rewatching, I have learned that the key to Avatar is Zuko and Iroh and their dynamic. Before discussing that, I will mention my minor issues. Starting off, there are a few episodes I don't like all that much. However, others like The Avatar State, The Swamp, and City of Walls and Secrets, so this is a nitpick. I also think Azula is underutilized and not as cool as people say. She feels more like the generic OP final boss archetype than the complex character she would become. Also, some of her lines are a bit too sassy and obnoxious for me, sounding like a high school popular girl. Long Feng is also just kind of there, but his voice is very cool. However, everything else is perfect. The story progresses very naturally, moving from finding Aang a teacher to trying to find out how to protect Ba Sing Se to the inevitable final battle that does not disappoint. Some of my favorite fights in the series are here. The showdown between Aang and Azula in The Drill, Toph's incredible victory in The Blind Bandit, and the final battle in Crossroads of Destiny are all amazing in their choreography and emotion. Episodes like Zuko Alone, Crossroads of Destiny, The Drill, Bitter Work, and The Tales of Ba Sing Se are beautiful pieces of media. The Tale of Iroh, Appa's kidnapping, and nearly all of Crossroads are some of the best moments in the series. This is just scratching the surface of Book 2's brilliance. However, the best aspect of Avatar has always been its characters. In this season, the characters are great. Aang has a very strong emotional dilemma in the series and he grows a lot. His trauma of losing Appa is truly heartbreaking and leads to a great subplot. Appa's disappearance proved that he was more than just a mascot and an important part of the show. The subplot gave us great episodes like The Serpent's Pass, The Desert, and Appa's Lost Days.  Katara also grows much more than in Book 1, which is actually saying quite a bit. Sokka is incredibly funny and has a few strong character moments. Toph is a fan favorite for good reason (though I think Sokka is overall the better character). I also really like Mai and Ty Lee and how their opposite personalities work off each other. However, Zuko and Iroh are the absolute highlight of the season. Iroh is my favorite character and Zuko is the most well-developed one. Their dynamic is by far the best in the show, and their relationship develops really well. This is Iroh's best season for humor, wisdom, and charm. The stuff with him and his tea shop is hilarious and his speeches are moving (R.I.P. Mako). The bond between these characters is so strong and it it why the emotional and epic moments work. One scene in Crossroads of Destiny is a good example. Iroh and Zuko are surrounded by evil earthbenders and Azula. The scene plays out like this: Iroh- Did I ever tell you how I got my nickname, 'The Dragon of the West"? Azula- I'm not interested in a lengthy anecdote, uncle. Iroh- It's more of a demonstration really. (Iroh drinks tea, Zuko looks at him and smiles, and Zuko moves behind Iroh as Iroh breathes fire). This scene is one of the greatest in the show as it perfectly encapsulates how well Zuko and Iroh know each other and how well they work together. I recommend watching this scene, this episode, and this season. It is my favorite in the Avatar universe, even above Book 3. The only other seasons of cartoons I might like more are seasons 4 and 8 of The Simpsons. This season is nearly flawless and I am so glad Shaymalan didn't make a movie out of this. However, the whole show is great and all 3 seasons rock. However, this one edges out Book 3 for Zuko and Iroh's dynamic.

As you can see the rating. 
It is a must watch.
The story builds in scope, the characters mature and are joined by top-notch additions, and the action never ceases to amaze.

This is a lot more exciting than the 1st book, and I really can't stop watching! 😂 The story is very compelling and all the characters (including the new characters) are really really amazing! The character developments are so captivating especially Zuko's, so I guess he's my favorite character now! The writing started strong and finished stronger with a very exciting ending, almost like a cliffhanger! The episodes are full of rich characterizations and some have gut-punch ending (like one of my favorite episodes: "Zuko Alone") Some episodes are heavy on funny moments too and I think that's one of the reasons that this show is so great. It perfectly blends humor and the serious and emotional aspects of the plot! Also, the action scenes are very thrilling to watch! Avatar is not just a cartoon show for kids, it's really so great that I think it shouldn't be labeled as just a children show. 

Special mention to my favorite episodes 😂
The Avatar State
The Cave of Two Lovers
Zuko Alone
The Chase
The Secret of the Fire Nation
City of Walls and Secrets
Tales of Ba Sing Se
Lake Laogai
The Earth King
The Crossroads of Destiny

Although the end arc of the season with the earth kingdom and Appas kidnapping was some of the weakest aspects of the series, the cliffhanger ending and betrayals were gripping and the characters of Azula and her crew as well as Zuko had great arcs and cemented them as my favorite characters along with of course Uncle Iroh. Toph was also a good addition to the series and her episode that focuses on the way different people learn and how a teacher must adapt really resonated with some of my academic experience. Add to that the compelling ideas about how a loss of a sense increases bending ability which alludes to the idea that bending acts as a sixth sense was a clever idea. When I first saw the season I must have watched it out of order because I remember is as my least favorite but upon re watching it is a significant step up from Season 1 and an ultimately great season overall.
Leaves from the vine got me crying to death.
best series in the word

The American television series that was commercially successful and acclaimed for its outstanding animation and plot. I've finally watched the whole thing from beginning to end and I can now say it's one of the best and most epic animated TV shows of all time. In a war-torn world of elemental magic, a young boy reawakens to undertake a dangerous mystic quest to fulfill his destiny as the Avatar, and bring peace to the world. Touching on mature themes like war, genocide and imperialism, it is also a series with a defined structure, full of compelling and well-developed characters and a funny sense of humor and good morals. Each episode is a great adventure in its own right, usually concluded with stunning action sequences. Great conclusion full of despair and hopelessness!
I love it, but season two is absolutely heartbreaking.

"LA BANDIDA CIEGA APARECE"
En el libro 2 de la historia de Aang vemos el avance de la aventura de nuestros héroes y el crecimiento de personajes que ellos ofrecen, sigo sorprendido de lo mucho que un personaje como Zuko puede ofrecer y evolucionar y realmente puedes empatizar con el, sus capas de complejidad en el pasado que le atormenta y no le deja vivir, simplemente es impresionante, a parte de uno u otro momento por allí, no creo que nada se compare en mi opinión a la entrada del nuevo acompañante del grupo Toph, una niña ciega que esta dotada con una extrema habilidad de tierra control y como sabemos mas adelante evoluciona para convertirse en la creadora del metal control, simplemente me encanta Toph, desde su diseño, su actitud y la voz que la dobla al español latino, es junto con Appa de los mejores diseños de la serie y por ultimo solo comentar hacia donde fue toda esta serie, que me di cuenta de lo poco que se comenta el estado Avatar y lo poco que se usa, porque el estado avatar en esta serie a diferencia de la de Korra es como una carga que Aang tiene que soportar por ser el elegido, mas que un poder que lo acompaña, esto cambia rumbo al final claro, pero no pude no notar esto y en general llegando al final de este libro, aunque no fue tan satisfactorio como el de la primera temporada, podemos seguir viendo la construcción de toda la trama como realmente cambia y evoluciona para un sorprendente final.

"The Tales of Ba Sing Se" is one of the best television episodes I have ever watched. It's a microcosm for all that is right with this show. That some of the tales are a minute or two long and still whole, still enjoyable, shows the care with which this series was created. One of the videos I watched on this episode specifically talked about the nuance of the characters, and perhaps that's what makes them so interesting. Whatever it is, I spent all day looking forward to getting off work and watching an episode or two. I'm addicted to good writing.

A nice return to the best animated show of all time. Him trying to figure out water bending and then earth. It was beautiful, because we feel the urgency to learn how to control these elements. We also get a lot of great character development for Zuko. Overall brilliant.

Such a good show. Fun, addicting, emotional and powerful in all kind of ways. The sophomore season focuses on evolving our main characters and adding a new bender to the group to round up the story development.

I rewatched this show that I remembered and loved from my childhood and found myself to be surprised by the amount of perfection this show has. Avatar: The Last Airbender has an incredible plot within all three of its seasons, beautifully played recursive themes, and perhaps the most perfectly executed examples of character development, especially through Zuko. Avatar is a series meant for all audiences.
With new cast members to guide returning favorites, the Second Season of Avatar lives up to the hype. 🌊🌍🔥🌪

Season two manages to outdo the fantastic pilot season. It brilliantly balances philosophical moments, whimsical comedy, and engrossing fight scenes. The pace and change of setting are fast enough to prevent maintain an engaging story but slow enough to create rich and meaningful tales with deep underlying messages, especially for a kids' show. But the most amazing part of this season is the characters. Each one develops in a great way that doesn't feel forced or too fast and maintains complex and nuanced relationships with the others. Toph adds a fresh new addition to the group.
Darker, more gritty and intense, and further developing the key characters as they go through lots of changes, Season 2 does everything it's supposed to do in spectacular fashion.
Avatar has figured its pace out. It's nearly flawless.

Season 2 is great.  I don't know if I prefer it to the first season or not but the season retains the great characters from the first season and adds some new favorites of mine.  The ending of season 2 (book 2) was amazing where the villians actually won and defeated the heroes.
An already strong season is followed up by a sequel season that literally improves upon every aspect of the show. At this point, anyone who has seen it knows this show will be immortal

The plot, the characters development, the life lessons, the amazing animation, the fantastic wonder that is bending. Even though this may be targeted at kids, you'll be surprised by how much a ""grown up"" can learn and cherish in it.

Season 2 saw the introduction of Toph Beifong, who is such an intriguing character that adds so much to the show. I could go on and on about how her character serves the plot in so many ways. Konietzko made such a good choice when he decided to make her character a girl rather than a man, as it served to subvert a lot of gender stereotypes, which is a popular theme in ATLA, but also just added spice to the show. 10/10
A "heroes journey" wrapped in a  "good versus evil" told as a "coming of age" tale. An incredible story for a children's show. The directing, humor, themes, characters, music, culture, all of it.

Wow, I never thought there will be a season of a show that was as good as the empire strikes back, this is one of the best seasons of all time, it has some of the best character arcs, episodes, figths and animations of all time, you can fight me in this but is personally my favorite season of Avatar, it has some great episodes as; Zuko alone, tales of Ba sing se, Apaa's lost days, the puppetmaster and of course the crossroads of destiny, Zuko's journey in this season is amazing the same for Aang, I think that my favorite episode from the whole series is Zuko Alone;because  this episode just goes so deep into my favorite character it tells you the story of a kid a scared kid that loses everything; his mother, his kingdom, and it says to the character that, his past will never be gone, his past will always be with him, his identity, and he must learn how to live with it, even if the society rejects him everytime he tries to do something good, that I like the most about this season is that for a moment all the characters are happy and you as a spectator want your characters to be happy but that will never happend because is not realistic at all, so I will give Avatar the last airbender a 10 out of 10

The second season outdoes the first! I did not believe this was possible! The story arcs of Zuko and Aapa are phenomenal. An exhibition of masterful storytelling and art! This show is for all ages and all times. Truly a gem!
Even better than the last, it's a satisfying middle chapter with all the good stuff we expect, all leading to and notionally kicking cliffhanger.
somehow it better better the season one!
Better than season one, which is saying something.
Season two of the masterpiece show considerably extends the mythology and story, and really expands the characters and adds new ones!

Season 2 expands the cast, and delves deeper into the characters it follows. This is especially true with Iroh and Zuko, including a touching backstory following Iroh and his late son. Concludes with questions about the Zuko's motivations and a thrilling final episode.
